Economist David Ricardo's theory of comparative advantage explains how countries trade today, emphasizing specialization and mutual benefits even if one country is more efficient in producing all goods. Ricardo argued that resources, especially labor, are immobile between countries, influencing trade dynamics. David Ricardo's theory of comparative advantage emphasizes specialization and trade based on opportunity cost rather than absolute production costs. Countries with differing opportunity costs have a comparative advantage in different goods, leading to gains from trade. The theory of comparative advantage, based on opportunity cost, states that countries should specialize in goods they can produce well and trade for goods they produce less efficiently.
